text.string:
All in all, it’s not easy to decide the best approach for dealing with misbehaviour. Both Clive and Andrew have valid arguments.

However one thing is pretty clear. Dealing with incidents and investigating suspected fraud and corruption, even relatively small incidents like this, is hard work and stressful. There can be unintended consequences whatever you do.

All in all, it’s not easy to decide the best approach for dealing with misbehaviour. Both Clive and Andrew have valid arguments.
However one thing is pretty clear. Dealing with incidents and investigating suspected fraud and corruption, even relatively small incidents like this, is hard work and stressful. There can be unintended consequences whatever you do.

text.string:
Preventing Fraud and Corruption, or detecting and dealing with it at an early stage is certainly preferable to investigating and addressing systematic misbehaviour or complex fraud.

It's worth investing up-front in the development of an anti-fraud culture by talking openly with employees about the risks, and with them detecting the warning signs early before too much damage is done. Prevention is so much more effective than cure!

text.string: When investigation is necessary however, there is still no cause for panic. A carefully controlled investigation is sometimes needed to discover and address the root causes of serious incidents, and to return the organization to normal. Even with investigation, the long term objective is to establish and support a culture resistant to future incidents of fraud and corruption.
